did.unittitle: Robert B. Fisher photograph collection and papers

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: This collection chiefly consists of photographs collected by Robert B. Fisher, but also includes his subject files and a small quantity of writings related to the history of photography, 1840-1998.

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: The Robert B. Fisher Photograph Collection and Papers were acquired by Peter E. Palmquist from Fisher, probably in 2002.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Restricted Fragile Materials in Box 34 (computer disks): Restricted fragile material. Reference copies of electronic files may be requested. Consult Access Services for further information.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Robert Burns Fisher Photograph and Papers are the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Robert B. Fisher Photograph Collection and Papers. Yale Collection of Western Americana, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.

relatedmaterial.head: Associated Materials
relatedmaterial.p: Robert B. Fisher Collection of Views of Europe (94.R.30). The Getty Research Institute.
Dr. Robert B. Fisher Collection. Museum of Local History, Fremont, California.

bioghist.head: Robert B. Fisher (1919-2004)
bioghist.p: In 1950, Robert Burns Fisher moved to Washington Township, California, and established a medical practice in San Jose. Fisher was keenly interested in local history, especially pioneer families who settled the area. He researched and sought the preservation of historic resources in Southern Alameda County. In 1962, he founded Mission Peak Heritage Foundation in Fremont, California. Fisher was an expert on European photography and a collector photographs, as well as a contributor of articles on the history of photography to the Journal of the West and Daguerreian Annual .

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This collection chiefly consists of photographs collected by Robert B. Fisher, but also includes his subject files and a small quantity of writings related to the history of photography, 1840-1998.

Photographs in the collection include cased photographs, stereographs, glass transparencies, and lantern slides. The collection includes a particularly rich variety of stereograph formats, including daguerreotype stereographs, ambrotype stereographs, tintype stereographs, glass stereographs, salted paper print stereographs, tissue stereographs, and card stereographs. The collection also provides visual documentation of the Niagara Falls region and the Great Britain during the middle of the nineteenth century. Photographers and stereograph publishers with significant quantities of photographic material in the collection include Edward Anthony, Platt Delascus Babbitt, Bierstadt Brothers, Keystone View Company, Langenheim Brothers, London Stereoscopic Company, New York Stereoscopic Company, and Underwood & Underwood.

Printed material in the collection includes illustrated articles, tear sheets, and prints with illustrations primarily published during the nineteenth century that Fisher compiled principally as resources for identifying photographic images.
Papers in the collection relate mainly to Fisher's photographic collection and the history of photography, as well as drafts of his articles in the Journal of the West and Daguerreian Annual .

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Cased Photographs, 1840-circa 1860. II. Stereographs, 1850-1975. III. Glass Transparencies and Lantern Slides, circa 1850-circa 1921. IV. Copy Photographs, circa 1980-circa 1997. V. Printed Material, 1842-1932. VI. Papers, 1977-1998.

did.unittitle: Cased Photographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series I is organized into four subseries: Daguerreotypes, Ambrotypes, Tintype, and Cases.
The contents of each subseries are arranged alphabetically under headings for identified creators, followed by items with unidentified creators

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of cased photographs, which are usually daguerreotypes, ambrotypes, or tintypes mounted in sturdy, boxlike cases. It includes thirty-nine daguerreotypes, two ambrotypes, and one tintype, as well as seven examples of empty cases.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note

did.unittitle: Stereographs

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series II is organized into seven subseries: Daguerreotype Stereographs, Ambrotypes Stereographs, Tintype Stereographs, Glass Stereographs, Salted Paper Print Stereographs, Stereographs, Tissue Stereographs, and Card Stereographs.

Headings in each subseries are arranged alphabetically by identified creators followed by items with unidentified creators. Items under each name are arranged either chronologically, alphabetically by title, or sequentially by stereograph number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of stereoscopic photographs in different formats, including daguerreotypes, ambrotypes, tintypes, glass, salted paper print, and tissue stereographs, as well as general stereograph cards that possess albumen and silver gelatin photographic prints.

Stereographs are double photographic prints that depict the same image taken from two slightly different perspectives and mounted on cards. Viewing the two-dimensional images through a stereoscope creates the illusion of a three-dimensional image to the viewer.
Entries for stereographs in each subseries include their titles, numbers on the mounts, and their series. The entries also document if no numbers or series information exists.
Entries may occasionally include descriptions of the images to clarify the subjects of the stereographs.

Glass Transparencies and Lantern Slides

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Series III is organized into six subseries: Glass Transparencies, Magic Lantern Slides with Movement, Magic Lantern Slides, Panorama Lantern Slides, Lantern Slides by Identified Photographers, and Lantern Slides by Unidentified Photographers.

Headings in each subseries are arranged alphabetically by identified creators followed by items with unidentified creators. Items under each name are arranged either chronologically, alphabetically by title, or sequentially by lantern slide number.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series consists of glass transparencies and lantern slides, which are formats designed for viewing by transmitted light. The material chiefly consists of transparent positive photographs, as well as some transparent non-photographic images that are designed for projection viewing or as intermediates for reproduction.
Individual titles and dates of lantern slides were not captured during processing the collection.
